abstract.p: Justin Gimelstob beats Christopher Rochus in first round of US Open (M)

block.p: Justin Gimelstob bounded forward furiously, shocked and screaming, the sound of his voice slicing through the suddenly quiet stadium.
''No way!'' he yelled, his face reddening. ''No way!''
Justin Gimelstob bounded forward furiously, shocked and screaming, the sound of his voice slicing through the suddenly quiet stadium.
''No way!'' he yelled, his face reddening. ''No way!''

In the fourth set against Christopher Rochus, Gimelstob, a native of Livingston, N.J., had just been called for a fault on a hard serve that appeared to sneak inside the line. The line judge retracted her call, but the chair refused to accept the revision.

This produced more protestations from Gimelstob, who refused to continue playing until a referee from the United States Tennis Association ruled on the play. Boos showered down from a crowd that had been roaring its praises of the 89th-ranked Gimelstob moments before.

''I didn't feel bad because I was right,'' Gimelstob said of the hometown crowd rooting against him for several points. Then he grinned. ''But it is remarkable how I have the ability to turn a 100 percent Gimelstob crowd against me in one point. It's just an innate ability I have. I have the ability to keep people in a stadium. To keep people in there rooting for me is another question.''

He would go on to lose the next game but win the match in a tie breaker, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, 7-6 (4), powering aces that skirted the center line while botching easy volleys. It was an impassioned and unpredictable performance with 34 aces and 49 unforced errors.
After the match, John McEnroe approached Gimelstob, perhaps recognizing a kindred spirit.

''McEnroe came into the locker room and said, 'I thought you were going to say, ''You can't be serious.'' ' '' Gimelstob said. ''But I think it's been established that there's only one guy who can freak out like that and then win the next game, and it's not me.''
